Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Proposal: Acute response of benthic hardbottom communities to oil exposure in the deep Gulf of Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past 20 years of work in the deep Gulf of Mexico we have assembled a large database on over 40 sites with chemosynthetic communities and 14 natural sites with extensive cold-water coral development. As a result of the ongoing oil leak at the Deep Water Horizon rig, some of these sites are very likely to be exposed to high concentrations of hydrocarbons and dispersant. Visitation, imaging, and sampling in the very near future at a subset of these sites will provide timely information on any acute impacts on benthic fauna, as well as provide ground-truthing of data suggesting that the oil/dispersant mixture is spreading along density gradients at depth.
We propose to revisit sites where we have ongoing studies, including pre-exposure tissue and live coral samples, and well-marked and navigated mosaics of coral and coral/tubeworm communities. A site in MMS lease block VK 826 and another in MC 751 are identified as high-priority sites with extant mosaics, excellent pre-existing macrofauna sample sets, and are currently monitored with time series sediment traps. A third high-priority site is in MMS lease Block MC 294, within 7 miles of the leak site. This site harbors a typical seep community of mussels and tubeworms. Numerous others could be visited if ongoing plume modeling and ground-truthing work suggests other important areas or depths in the Gulf of Mexico for study.
At each site visited, we will conduct high resolution imaging of the hard ground megafaunal communities for comparisons to similar imagery collected last year and make a series of macrofauna collections for a suite of analyses. These analyses will include analysis of hydrocarbon load (tissue PAHs), Comet assays to assess DNA damage, analysis of phospholipids fatty acid biomarkers from bacteria in coral mucous, and also experiments with living Lophelia pertusa for growth studies under laboratory conditions.
Broader Impacts
For the first time in US history, we are dealing with a massive leakage and spread of oil and trial dispersants (potentially much more toxic to life than the oil itself), which have been directly injected at over 1500m into the deep sea. The scale of this disaster dwarfs any previous oil spills and how plumes of these substances will travel in the deep sea and what their effects on the benthos will be is still almost completely unknown. As a result, there is a critical need to assess the impact on deep-sea megafauna communities and communicate those results as soon as possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Deepwater Horizon Incident was the largest accidental release of oil into the marine environment that has ever occurred. This unprecedented event resulted in damage to the greater Gulf of Mexico ecosystem that is still being characterized and quantified. While numerous groups have been investigating the impacts of the oil spill on shallow water ecosystems, including beaches and salt marshes, the effects on the deep-water communities that lie in close proximity to the site of the disaster have remained undescribed. On the final dive of the Oct-Nov MMS (now the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, or BOEM) cruise, a site at 1370 m depth in Mississippi Canyon (MC) lease block 294 exhibited distinct visual evidence of impact from the spill. This site was dominated by Paramuricea biscaya, a species of long-lived gorgonian coral. There were numerous colonies of this coral that were covered in a brown substance, releasing copious amounts of mucous, and had extensive areas of bare skeleton. This site was extensively photographed, physical markers were placed, and a limited number of samples acquired. It was then decided to re-task the NSF-funded cruise scheduled for Dec 2010 with the DSV Alvin to investigate this heavily impacted site and to explore the surrounding area for additional sites with the AUV Sentry.

On the December cruise, the main coral site in MC294 as well as the surrounding area were comprehensively photographed and a series of samples taken for additional analyses. The majority of the gorgonian colonies exhibited signs of stress response including excessive mucous production and retracted polyps. A collected colony exhibited varying degrees of tissue removal, spicule enlargement, and mucous production. At the base and along the main axis of the colony, bare skeleton was observed entirely devoid of tissue. At increasing distances from the basal point of attachment, less extensive tissue loss resulted in the exposure of the calcite skeletal elements that are normally embedded in the tissue layers and coenenchyme. These sclerites were still in their normal position in the form a polyp, but appeared enlarged. Along the smaller branches, there were numerous polyps with different degrees of tissue loss and potentially enlarged sclerites. All of these areas of the colony had been covered by the brown substance upon initial investigation. Near the tips of the branches, which were not covered by the substance, a few polyps still appeared normal.

All of these findings have been disseminated to the wider scientific community as well as the public. During the cruise, there was live coverage on the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution’s Dive and Discover web site. In addition, one of the collaborative proposals funded by NSF supported a documentary film crew. Also during the cruise, Silvia Earle paid us a visit and brought along a documentary crew with her as well. Dr. Cordes also gave a series of presentations describing the findings of this project. These included the “Deepwater Horizon (DWH) Oil Spill Principal Investigator's Conference” hosted by the National Science and Technology Council's Joint Sub-Committee on Ocean Science and Technology in St. Petersburg, FL; the National Council for Society and the Environment’s “Our Changing Oceans Conference” in Washington DC; a seminar in the Department of Earth and Environmental Science at the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia PA; and a lecture to the general public and press at the Metcalf Institute for Marine & Environmental Reporting Annual Lecture Series, University of Rhode Island Graduate School of Oceanography.
